docs.lead_paragraph: War veterans who have lost their upper limbs have found that replicating their complex actions with robotic arms can be excruciatingly difficult.
docs.abstract: Corporal Sebastian Gallegos, one of over 1,570 American service members who have had their limbs amputated because of injuries in Afghanistan, is part of a small vanguard of military amputees who are benefiting from new advances in upper limb technology; has received pioneering surgery known as targeted muscle reinnervation intended to simplify use of prosthetic arms by amplifying nerve signals that control the prosthesis. (Series: The Hard Road Back)

docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, on the eve of the Sundance Film Festival, the independent movie world was fixated on trends like the emergence of dozens of entertainment dot-coms, the growing impact of digital cinema and the strange convergence many saw between independent-flavored films put out by the major studios and Hollywood-flavored films made by many independent filmmakers. Now, with the publicists and the corporate jets and the struggling filmmakers converging on Salt Lake City for tonight's opening of the 20th Sundance Film Festival, the landscape is strikingly different.
docs.abstract: Independent movie world prepares for opening of Sundance Film Festival in Salt Lake City; landscape has changed strikingly in year; many of dot-coms have collapsed, but those that survive are expected to be significant presence at festival; digital cinema has failed so far to produce flood of fresh voices; predictions that Hollywood studios would unleash flood of independent-style films are now largely forgotten (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Royal Society in Great Britain, the world’s oldest continuous scientific society, is striving to stay relevant in the modern world.
docs.abstract: The Royal Society in Great Britain, the world’s oldest continuous scientific society, enjoys a storied past, but is striving to stay relevant in the modern world; some of the Society's publications remain cutting-edge, but it faces stiff competition from the United States and other nations where billions in funding are up for grabs.

docs.lead_paragraph: MODERN science is accustomed to bigness. In five years, the world's most powerful particle accelerator will be in operation at the CERN physics laboratory outside Geneva. The $4 billion accelerator will give physicists the tools they need to search for scientific prizes like the elusive Higgs boson, a particle believed to be the origin of mass and weight in the universe. But when the accelerator starts up, scientists will not necessarily need to travel to Switzerland to conduct their experiments. Instead, they will be able to work together remotely, using a federally financed project called the Grid Physics Network, or GriPhyN (pronounced GRIFF-in), a system that can be used in real time by researchers working on experiments that require vast amounts of computational power.
docs.abstract: Internet-based collaboration reaches new heights in business and science; examples include Grid Physics Network, which allows researchers around the world to work together on experiments at CERN physics laboratory in Switzerland, Freeverse Software, New York-based company whose far-flung programmers use e-mail messages as primary means of collaboration, and Web-based collaboration of several engineering companies on design and manufacture of wireless headset for new Chrysler minivan; photo (M)
